sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_2:
To find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

det(A) = a(ei − fh) − b(di − fg) + c(dh − eg)

where the matrix A is:

\begin{bmatrix} 
a & b & c \\ 
d & e & f \\ 
g & h & i 
\end{bmatrix}

In our case, the matrix is:

\begin{bmatrix} 
5 & 3 & 2 \\ 
1 & -2 & 0 \\ 
3 & 1 & 5 
\end{bmatrix}

So, a = 5, b = 3, c = 2, d = 1, e = -2, f = 0, g = 3, h = 1, and i = 5.

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

det(A) = 5((-2)(5) - (0)(1)) - 3((1)(5) - (0)(3)) + 2((1)(1) - (3)(-2))

det(A) = 5((-10) - 0) - 3(5 - 0) + 2(1 - (-6))

det(A) = 5(-10) - 3(5) + 2(7)

det(A) = -50 - 15 + 14

det(A) = -51

So, the determinant of the given 3x3 matrix is -51.
